title: Young boy can't stop making silly faces during This Morning interview with Jeremy Corbyn
text:
It's not every day that Leader of the Opposition appears on This Morning to discuss policy, but one boy was determined not to be overcome by the gravitas of the situation as he was interviewed alongside Jeremy Corbyn on the sofa.

Cystic fibrosis sufferer Luis Walker, 9, from Horam, East Sussex was seen pulling a series of funny faces as he watched his face in the monitor.

Luke previously hit the headlines when he campaigned for bosses at Vertex to bring down the cost of Orkambi - hailed as a 'wonder drug' - to help him 'feel much better and not have to spend so much time in hospital'.

The drug company bowed to pressure after Jeremy Corbyn backed his, and the Labour Leader appeared on This Morning alongside Luis and his mother Christina, 47, to discuss the case.

But it appeared Luis was distracted in the interview, and was seen puffing his cheeks, pouting and grinning cheekily in Jeremy's direction throughout the segment.

Luis Walker, 9, from Horam, appeared distracted through his interview on This Morning as he pulled silly faces in the direction of the Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn

Luis and his mother Christina, 46, appeared on the morning programme alongside Jeremy, with the little boy pulling silly faces in the Labour leader's direction

Cystic fibrosis, which affects around 10,000 people in the UK, leads to sticky mucus building up in the lungs and digestive system.

The life-extending cystic fibrosis drugs will be available on the NHS next month after a deal was struck following four years of deadlock over their price tag.

Up to 5,000 patients in England will benefit from three £104,000-a-year pills after the deal with Boston-based maker Vertex.

Vertex was slammed by Jeremy Corbyn in his conference speech for refusing to drop the price of the drug.

Jeremy appeared on the programme after helping cystic fibrosis sufferer Luis gain access to a vital drug on the NHS

While his mother opened up about their battle to access a vital cystic fibrosis drug, Luis was seen pouting, puffing his cheeks and beaming cheekily

He also vowed to change the way drugs were patented to stop big pharma firms exploiting their monopoly.

The Labour leader appeared on the programme with Luis and Christina, as they opened up to Richard and Judy.

But Luis appeared distracted throughout the interview as he pulled a series of silly faces.

While his mother opened up about the challenges of getting access to the drug around the world, Luis could be seen raising his eyebrows cheekily in the direction of Jeremy.

The nine-year-old was seen pulling silly faces in the direction of the Labour leader throughout the interview

Rather than look at Richard and Judy as they interviewed his mother, instead the little boy appeared enthralled by Jeremy, and was seen switching between a cheeky grin and a frown.

The nine-year-old boy has spent his whole life in and out of hospital with painful lung infections and other symptoms of cystic fibrosis.

Luis currently needs at least four hours of treatment and more than 20 tablets per day.

But he will start taking Orkambi within the next few weeks, helping his breathing by reducing the build-up of mucus in his lungs and giving him more energy to play with friends and go to school.

Despite the severity of the topic, Luis appeared distracted by the bright lights and cameras of the studio, and couldn't stop pulling silly faces

Luis appeared uninterested in questions from Richard and Judy and instead appeared distracted by This Morning's cameras

Luis appeared distracted by the bright lights and camera in the studio, and switched between smiling and frowning while his mother was interviewed on This Morning

His mother told presenters Richard and Judy on This Morning that she hoped the drug would be 'the best Christmas present ever’.

She said: 'It won't get any worse for Luis, and we hear the burden is lessening for people over time.'

Jeremy was vocal about his support for Luis and his mother, saying: 'I took the case up, and wrote to the government and the company as well.

He added: 'We met at the Labour party had a really good chat there.'

WHAT IS CYSTIC FIBROSIS? Cystic fibrosis is an incurable genetic disease that affects around 70,000 people worldwide. A defective gene causes a build-up of mucus in the airways, making it increasingly difficult to breathe over time. Mucus also blocks the natural release of digestive enzymes, meaning the body does not break down food as it should. Signs and symptoms: A persistent cough that produces thick mucus (sputum)

Wheezing

Breathlessness

Exercise intolerance

Repeated lung infections

Inflamed nasal passages or a stuffy nose While healthy people cough naturally, that does not happen for people with CF. Eventually, lung function depletes to the point that sufferers will need a double lung transplant to survive. Source: Cystic Fibrosis Foundation

And when Richard suggested that the family had 'won the battle but not won the war', Christina agreed.

She explained that despite the success for Luis, there were patients from across the UK who were still waiting for access to the drug.

Christina said: 'Wales and Northern Ireland are still waiting, it's not over till they get it.

'Half of the patients worldwide don't get this drug and Vertex don't even try to sell to patients in places like Poland.'
description: Luis Walker, 9, from East Sussex, appeared on This Morning alongside Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, to discuss the youngster's successful campaign to lower the cost of cystic fibrosis drugs.
